author: AARON CLAVERIE
title: TEMECULA: Huge milestone for Temecula Parkway offramp project
text:
BY AARON CLAVERIE / STAFF 16, 2015 5:03 p.m. TEMECULA: Huge milestone for Temecula Parkway offramp project More The City of Temecula purchased the ampm gas station to help create space for utility relocation involved with the constructon of the new offramp at Temecula Parkway. , FRANK BELLINO, FILE PHOTO Related article » The long wait may soon be over.
The city of Temecula this week approved agreements with Caltrans and local utility companies that will allow workers to start building the new interchange at Temecula Parkway in the spring of 2016.
“This is a huge milestone,” said Thomas Garcia, the city of Temecula’s public works director. “Staff has been working on securing these agreements for over a year.”
When complete, the new interchange is expected to shrink the long line of cars that forms ahead of the Temecula Parkway exit on southbound Interstate 15.
During rush hour or when there are special events at the Pechanga Resort & Casino, the line can back up for more than a mile, causing ripple effect congestion that impacts the entire Interstate 15 corridor in Temecula.
On weekends, the exit also can become congested by traffic headed to wineries in the southern half of Wine Country and Vail Lake, which hosts extreme races that can attract crowds of 10,000 or more.
Work on the new interchange is expected to start in the spring of 2016, possibly in April or May, with completion expected in December of 2017 or early 2018, said Amer Attar, the city’s principal engineer.
“We’re getting closer and closer,” he said Friday.
The $45 million project has been on the city’s capital improvement project master list for more than a decade. Every member of the Temecula City Council who has given a state of the city address has mentioned it during his or her speech.
For the people who live in Wolf Creek and Redhawk it has been an elusory dream, an oasis on the horizon that never materializes.
City officials have said it has taken so long to build due to the complications that arise from the use of federal money, which requires extra environmental reports and different types of clearances.
A few years ago, a new challenge arose when the city started looking at relocating the utilities that would be impacted by construction. This process led the city to purchase the ampm at the corner of Temecula Parkway and Old Town Front Street, which it has been leasing out since 2013.
With the ampm land in hand, the city started talking to Caltrans and the various utilities on where and how lines and pipes would be moved. Those talks led to the agreements that were approved this week.
Attar said the ampm will be demolished in the near future to make way for the relocation of the utilities. That action should serve as the first tangible sign that work on the interchange is ready to begin.
Cecilie Nelson, a real estate agent who lives in Wolf Creek, said the new interchange will do wonders for the entire region, thinning traffic on the residential streets that have been used as Temecula Parkway avoidance routes by locals.
Garcia and Attar said the next step is requesting permission to bid the project from Caltrans and the Federal Highways Administration, which should be done by the end of the year. Once those agencies sign off, the city can bid the project and construction can begin.
The money to pay for the interchange includes more than a million in federal dollars, more than $4 million from the Indian Gaming Special Distribution Fund, more than $1 million in county money and millions more from a regional transportation account that is fed by development fees. Officials say it will take about 18 months to build.
